text: software is malleable like sand is malleable. Software has a very tiny cell size, like sand, and as such is very tedious to construct anything. It is not really a flexible material, it is merely a microscopic rigid material, and has to be used in great abundance to achieve good things. The fact that we are not in an era of interchangeable parts means that people have to build their castles over and over custom made, instead of using pre-fab small pieces like lego. Lego is arguably the greatest toy ever invented, founded on the 8 bump brick which snaps together in many ways, but always perfectly. We need better data interchange between pieces and then it will be a much more flexible medium. It's not locked down really; none of the pieces snap together that well.

The fact that we are not in an era of interchangeable parts means that people have to build their castles over and over custom made, instead of using pre-fab small pieces like lego. Lego is arguably the greatest toy ever invented, founded on the 8 bump brick which snaps together in many ways, but always perfectly. text:
Hi all! I've been working on a web development platform called Boomla for 14 years, I'm sort of coming out of the bush these days. <https://boomla.com/> I also call it a Website OS as it is a platform where websites are first-class citizens.
It is a server-side platform, with its own object-oriented filesystem, functional execution model, package management solution, etc. It can currently be programmed in JavaScript on the server, but it will support multiple languages in the future.
It also provides a drag&drop user-interface for end-users to let them build websites. But that's optional, you could build a different frontend for it.
It has a web based IDE and lots of documentation. I made the decision early to focus on the platform and not write any new programming language. :smile:
It was designed to be low on maintenance. The platform is fast and rock solid stable. Developers tend to agree that the most interesting part of the system is the object oriented filesystem with lots of interesting properties.
I'm glad for the existence of the group, looking forward to interesting conversations!

elements.text: Hi all! I've been working on a web development platform called Boomla for 14 years, I'm sort of coming out of the bush these days.

I also call it a Website OS as it is a platform where websites are first-class citizens.
It is a server-side platform, with its own object-oriented filesystem, functional execution model, package management solution, etc. It can currently be programmed in JavaScript on the server, but it will support multiple languages in the future.
It also provides a drag&drop user-interface for end-users to let them build websites. But that's optional, you could build a different frontend for it.
It has a web based IDE and lots of documentation. I made the decision early to focus on the platform and not write any new programming language.

It was designed to be low on maintenance. The platform is fast and rock solid stable. Developers tend to agree that the most interesting part of the system is the object oriented filesystem with lots of interesting properties.
I'm glad for the existence of the group, looking forward to interesting conversations!

text: very interesting! I am also working on a somewhat comparable file-system-alternative, although it is more of a toy project. It shares the approach of making intermediate-nodes (directories) also hold data, but the nodes interact very differently. I'm curious to read more about the OO-interactions of yours.

Yeah I think I understood the basics of it, it's a neat idea to do prototypial inheritance via these type links.
My system is online (<https://s-ol.nu>, current beta on <https://ba.s-ol.nu>) but largely undocumented at the moment. I am writing my BA thesis about it currently, but honestly the drafts riddled with uncontextualised notes and links etc. are a bit embarrasing to share :stuck_out_tongue:

text: in my system there is no way of incuding/reusing behaviour from other sources (except via language-specific ways of including code, but that doesn't count) and the need for that is very obvious. Basically, there is only a set of globally known types and something more or less analogous to your .Include mechanism, but they are currently defined outside of the system itself. I'm thinking of integrating them so that a container can add to this set for it's children only...

text:
In software, the shovels and buckets are also made of sand, and you can sculpt yourself an excavator (and the things made from sand can be used without crumbling apart)

But yes, as soon as you try to alter anything made of sand, it can crumble. So maybe we need sand-bricks that are easy to reassemble without having to think about the sand they're made of?

Anyway, nice analogy. Software is super powerful and expressive, but we need to find ways to make it less like working with sand. The tricky part is that we've got to use sand (at least initially) to shape the sand into something less sandy.

text: it’s not just whoever showed up first—most programmers were originally women, for example

text: I mean narrowly whoever showed up first to any given product or language or API or community.

text: it’s definitely a huge contributing factor—especially since people with resources and support and a safety net are more likely able to tinker with new things. was just pointing out that there are a myriad of structural factors beyond just first-past-the-post

text:
Yeah, I didn't intend for it to be comprehensive.

But can you give examples of some other factors? I'm looking to identify my blind spots.

elements.text:
Yeah, I didn't intend for it to be comprehensive.

But can you give examples of some other factors? I'm looking to identify my blind spots.

text: i meant the ones that I at least would consider obvious—eg: tons of computing, especially in poorer countries, happens on mobile. and those systems aren’t very friendly to open source unless you also own a laptop

text: another thing is like community/discrimination keeping people out or forcing them out after a while

text: another thing is just straight up state violence: turing was in the middle of inventing a really interesting take on chaos theory before anyone knew it as chaos theory before the british government murdered him

text: I interpret "whoever happened to show up first" not as who did the first acts of programming / computer science (in many cases, women), but rather as whatever power structures were imposed first are what dominated. I'm thinking ethea like top-down militarism, capitalism, libertarianism, anarchism.

elements.text: I interpret "whoever happened to show up first" not as who did the first acts of programming / computer science (in many cases, women), but rather as whatever power structures were imposed first are what dominated. I'm thinking ethea like top-down militarism, capitalism, libertarianism, anarchism.

text: It's easy to imagine how different computing would be if it were entirely relegated to artists as a medium for creative expression, and were never adopted (some might say co-opted) by business and the military. Or were it initially seen as a polytechnic trade or craft, rather than an avenue to research mathematics and physics. Imagine if the computational substrate were emergent from nature, like leather or fabric, rather than emergent from mechanics and electronics — how that would change the dissemination of knowledge and practice in the early days. (I don't mean emergent from "fiber arts" — I know about card weaving and there's a loom in my house. I mean emergent from fiber itself.)

Imagine if the computational substrate were emergent from nature, like leather or fabric, rather than emergent from mechanics and electronics — how that would change the dissemination of knowledge and practice in the early days. (I don't mean emergent from "fiber arts" — I know about card weaving and there's a loom in my house. I mean emergent from fiber itself.)

text: hm—we’re definitely on the same page here—but I think there usually are societies and power structures pre-existing before capitalism/militarism/whatever comes in and takes over—I guess that’s my only point

text:
Hey there! :wave:
I've been working with a friend on *CodistAI* (<http://codist-ai.com/>) for the past two months: it's about navigating and understanding source code in visual and more intuitive way. We render any code as a graph which is diggable, interactive and augmented (with quality and security info).
We came up with that idea bc working on different projects and every time the same question "WTF is happening here ?!" especially when I face some kind of spaghetti code.
Also I'm deeply interested in any way possible to make software development more dev friendly! :nerd_face:

I'm happy to join this channel!

attachments.title: Codist AI
attachments.text: CodistAI est une plateforme de visualisation graphique de code
